---

# Data Visualizations with **ggplot2**


::: {.cell}

:::


## Warm-up+


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/aesthetics-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


. . .

What are the `aes`thetics in this plot?

What `geom`etric object is being plotted?

##  {background-color="#D4D4D4"}

::: {style="margin-top: 100px; font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
Univariate (One Variable) Visualizations -- For Numerical Data
:::

::: incremental
::: {style="color:#000000;"}
-   Histogram (or Dotplot)
-   Boxplot
-   Density Plot
:::
:::

## Histogram


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|2"}
ggplot(data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm)) + 
  geom_histogram() +
  labs(x = "Bill Length (mm)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/hist-1.png){fig-align='center' width=480}
:::
:::


## 

::: columns
::: {.column width="50"}
### Pros

-   Easy to inspect
-   Higher bars represent where data are relatively more common
-   Inspect shape of a distribution (skewed or symmetric)
-   Identify modes
:::

::: {.column width="50"}
### Cons

-   **Do not** plot raw data, plot summaries (counts) of the data!
-   Sensitive to `binwidth`
:::
:::

## Boxplot

::: columns
::: {.column width="70%"}

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|3"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_boxplot() + 
  labs(x = "Bill Length (mm)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/boxplot-1.png){width=480}
:::
:::

:::

::: {.column width="30%"}
-   What calculations are necessary to create a boxplot?

-   What are strengths of a boxplot?

-   What are weaknesses of a boxplot?
:::
:::

##  {background-color="#000000"}

![](images/boxplot_horst.png)

## Density Plot

::: columns
::: {.column width="70%"}

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|3"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm)) +
  geom_density() +
  labs(x = "Bill Length (mm)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/density-1.png){width=576}
:::
:::

:::

::: {.column width="30%"}
-   A smooth approximation to a variable's distribution
-   Plots density (as a proportion) on the y-axis
:::
:::

##  {background-color="#D4D4D4"}

::: {style="margin-top: 100px; font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
Bivariate (Two Variables) Visualizations -- For Numerical Data
:::

::: incremental
::: {style="color: #000000;"}
-   Scatterplots

-   Faceted Histograms

-   Side-by-Side Boxplots

-   Stacked Density Plots (Ridge Plots)
:::
:::

## Scatterplots


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='fragment'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|3"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(y = bill_length_mm, x = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "Bill Depth (mm)", 
       y = "Bill Length (mm)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/scatterplot-1.png){fig-align='center' width=576}
:::
:::


##  {background-color="#D4D4D4"}

::: {style="margin-top: 100px; font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
Multivariate Plots
:::

::: {style="color: #000000; font-size: 0.75em;"}
There are two main methods for adding a third (or fourth) variable into a data visualization:

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Colors**

-   creates colors for every level of a categorical variable
-   creates a gradient for different values of a quantitative variable
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Facets**

-   creates subplots for every level of a variable
-   labels each sub-plot with the value of the variable
:::
:::
:::

## Colors in Scatterplots -- Categorical Variable


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|4,9"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(y = bill_length_mm,
                     x = bill_depth_mm,
                     color = species)
       ) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "Bill Depth (mm)", 
       y = "Bill Length (mm)", 
       color = "Penguin Species")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/scatterplot-color-cat-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Colors in Scatterplots -- Numerical Variable


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|4,9"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(y = bill_length_mm,
                     x = bill_depth_mm,
                     color = body_mass_g)
       ) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "Bill Depth (mm)", 
       y = "Bill Length (mm)", 
       color = "Body Mass (g)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/scatterplot-color-num-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Facets in Scatterplots -- Categorical Variable


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|5"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(y = bill_length_mm,
                     x = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~ species) + 
  labs(x = "Bill Depth (mm)", 
       y = "Bill Length (mm)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/scatterplot-facets-cat-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Facets in Scatterplots -- Numerical Variable ðŸ«¤


::: {.cell layout-align="center" output-location='slide'}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|5"}
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(y = bill_length_mm,
                     x = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~ body_mass_g) + 
  labs(x = "Bill Depth (mm)", 
       y = "Bill Length (mm)")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/scatterplot-facets-num-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


# Summarizing Numerical Data

## 

<center>

::: {style="font-size: 2em;"}
Measures of Center
:::

</center>

::: columns
::: {.column width="55%"}
::: {style="color:#e28743;"}
**Not Resistant**
:::

Mean
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {style="color:#e28743;"}
**Resistant**
:::

Median
:::
:::

. . .

</br>
</br>

::: {.callout-tip}
# 60-second question

What does it mean for a statistic to be "resistant"?
:::

##

<center>

::: {style="font-size: 2em;"}
Measures of Spread
:::

</center>

::: columns
::: {.column width="55%"}
::: {style="color:#e28743;"}
**Not Resistant**
:::

Variance

Range
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {style="color:#e28743;"}
**Resistant**
:::

Inner Quartile Range (IQR)
:::
:::

</br>
</br>

::: {.callout-tip}
# 60-second question

Why are the variance and range not resistant? 
:::



##  {background-color="#D4D4D4"}

::: {style="margin-top: 100px; font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"}
Given this distribution...
:::


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/body-mass-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


. . .

<center>

::: {style="color: #0F4C81;"}
What measure of center would you use? Why?
:::

## For right skewed data...


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## For symmetric (and bimodal) data...


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](week2-day1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Point Estimates & Parameters

</br>

*Parameter*: True value of the statistic for the population of interest

</br>

. . .

*Point Estimate*: provides our best guess for the value of the parameter

</br>

. . .

::: {style="color:#e28743;"}
Estimates based on larger samples tend to be more accurate than those based on smaller samples.
:::

## Before Thursday...

Complete the **two** R tutorials 

* Visualizing Numerical Variables

* Summarizing Numerical Variables 

Linked in the Week 2 coursework!

::: {style="color:#e28743;"}
These are the individuals you will be working with for the next three weeks! Exchange contact information!
:::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
